title: Game Theory
subtitle: Incentive Compatibility and Nash Equilibrium: Bitcoin's Game Design
introduction: Bitcoin is a carefully designed game system. The interests of miners, users, and developers are balanced through clever incentive mechanisms. From the prisoner's dilemma of mining to the cost-benefit analysis of 51% attacks, Bitcoin demonstrates how to maintain system security through economic incentives rather than legal enforcement. This is a perfect real-world application of game theory.

sections.title: Prisoner's Dilemma: The Challenge of Cooperation

content.subtitle: Classic Prisoner's Dilemma
points: Individual vs Collective Rationality: Defection is the dominant strategy
Nash Equilibrium: Stable state where both parties defect
Social Dilemma: Individual optimum does not equal collective optimum
Value of Trust: Cooperation creates greater benefits

content.subtitle: Bitcoin's Solution
points: Changing the Payoff Matrix: Honest mining yields greater rewards than attacks
Repeated Games: Long-term benefits outweigh short-term cheating
Verifiability: Cheating is immediately detected
Sunk Costs: Attacks require enormous upfront investment

sections.title: Incentive Design: Making Selfishness Produce Cooperation

content.subtitle: Mining Incentives
points: Block Rewards: Direct returns for honest work
Transaction Fees: Priority for packaging high-value transactions
Orphan Block Penalties: Dishonest behavior leads to losses
Difficulty Adjustment: Automatic mechanism maintaining equilibrium

content.subtitle: Economic Security
points: Attack Costs: 51% attacks are economically infeasible
Incentive Compatibility: Personal interests align with system interests
Nash Equilibrium: Honesty is the optimal strategy
Self-Reinforcement: More participants make the system more secure

content.subtitle: Schelling Points
points: Focal Effect: Longest chain as natural focal point
Coordination Costs: Forks lead to value fragmentation
Network Effects: Rationality of following the majority
Path Dependence: Historical choices influence future

content.subtitle: Fork Games
points: Hard Forks: Incompatible rule changes
Soft Forks: Backward-compatible upgrades
Economic Voting: Market determines winners
UASF: User Activated Soft Forks

content.subtitle: Problem Essence
points: Unreliable Communication: Messages may be lost or tampered
Traitors Present: Some nodes may be malicious
Consensus Requirement: Honest nodes must reach agreement
Traditional Solution: Requires trusted third party

content.subtitle: Proof of Work Solution
points: Probabilistic Consensus: Longest chain converges probabilistically
Economic Cost: Betrayal requires paying a price
Asynchronous Network: No need for synchronized clocks
Open Participation: No identity authentication required

content.subtitle: Zero-Sum Characteristics of Traditional Finance

Systemic Risk: Too-big-to-fail moral hazard

content.subtitle: Bitcoin's Positive-Sum Potential

Information Transparency: Blockchain is publicly verifiable
Financial Inclusion: Permissionless participation
Value Creation: Network effects bring appreciation
